column2: Hey, you\xc2\x92re not going to believe this. I made up a joke and sent it\nin to Playboy. They printed it!'
I didn\xc2\x92t know Playboy prints jokes.'
Yeah, they print jokes, interviews, hard-hitting journalism. It\xc2\x92s not\njust about the pictures.'
That didn\xc2\x92t work on mom, it\xc2\x92s not going to work on us.'
(showing them the page) Here, check it out. It\xc2\x92s the first\none, too.'
That is funny. It was also funny when I made it up.'
What?'
I made that joke up.'
Uh, oh-oh, no you didn\xc2\x92t. I did.'
Yes, I did. I told it to Dan at work, and he said it was the funniest\njoke he\xc2\x92d ever heard.'
Hey, tell Dan, \xc2\x91Thanks.\xc2\x92'
What?'
I\xc2\x92m sorry, I was just reading the joke below it. Man, that one is\nfunny. (Ross grabs the magazine away from her.)'
Monica, you remember me telling you that joke, right?'
No.'
Seriously?'
Well, you tell a lot of jokes!'
Look, Chandler, it\xc2\x92s my joke. But, hey, if it makes you feel any\nbetter they don\xc2\x92t print the name, so it doesn\xc2\x92t really matter who gets credit,\nright?'
Yeah, I guess.'
(entering) Hey guys.'
(jumping up from his chair) Hey, Joey, Playboy\nprinted my joke.'
No, it\xc2\x92s my joke, it\xc2\x92s mine. You can call them, they\xc2\x92ll\ntell you.'
It\xc2\x92s my joke.'
It\xc2\x92s my joke.'
Whoa-whoa-whoa. Jokes? You guys know they have naked chicks in there,\nright?'
Dude, you have got to turn on Behind the Music. The band Heart\nis having a really tough time, and I think they may break up.'
Let\xc2\x92s go watch it at your place.'
Nah, Monica\xc2\x92s watching some cooking show. Come on, I don\xc2\x92t\nwant to miss when they were skinny.'
Chandler, Chandler, y\xc2\x92know what we should do? You and I should go out\nand get some new sunglasses.'
What? No, I want to watch this. (He turns on the television and the\nscreen is completely covered in snow). Did your cable go out?'
No, that\xc2\x92s VH-1. I gotta tell you, the music these kids listen\nto today . . . It\xc2\x92s like a lotta noise to me. I don\xc2\x92t know\xc2\x85'
Joey, why is your cable out?'
I uh, oh! Because, uh, I haven\xc2\x92t really paid the bill'
If you need money, will you please-please just let me loan you some\nmoney?'
No, Chandler. Look, forget about it, okay? Look, I know things have been a\nlittle tight since Janine moved out. Oh, was she hot. '
Whoa ho.'
I know! Yeah, but, look I can handle it. All right? Look, I can listen to\nthe radio, huh? And Ross gave me this great book (holds up the Playboy magazine).'
(picks up the phone) All right, you want to see if the joke stealer\nwill let us watch the show at his place?'
Sure.'
(with phone to ear, obviously hearing no dial tone) Paid your phone\nbill?'
Not so much.'
(entering) Hey.'
(relieved) It\xc2\x92s only you.'
Wh-wh-what are you doing?'
We are looking at a Playboy.'
Oh, I want to look too! (She runs over and sits down and checks out a\npicture). Yikes!'
So do you think that these pictures\xc2\x97Are, are they trying to tell a\nstory?'
Oh, yeah, sure. I mean, like in the case of this young woman, she has\nlost her clothes, so she rides naked on the horse, she\xc2\x92s crying out, \xc2\x91Where are\nthey, where are they?\xc2\x92'
Well, she\xc2\x92s not going to find them lying in the grass like that.'
Oh, yeah. Aw, remember the days when you used to go out to the barn,\nlift up your shirt, and bend over?'
Yeah.'
You see, now, I would date this girl. She\xc2\x92s cute, she\xc2\x92s\noutdoorsy, you know, and she knows how to build a fire. I mean, that\xc2\x92s got to come in\nhandy'
Okay, I\xc2\x92ve got a question. If you had to pick one of us to date,\nwho would it be?'
(thinks) I don\xc2\x92t know.'
Me neither.'
Rachel.'
What?!'
I don\xc2\x92t know. (Pause) Me neither.'
You forget how many great songs Heart had.'
Yeah.'
You know, Barracuda was the first song I learned to play on the keyboard.'
So, you heard it, you repeated it, so that must mean you wrote it.'
Oh, you guys, with this joke. I gotta say, I know I cracked up, but\nI\xc2\x92m not even sure I got it.'
What, you didn\xc2\x92t get it? The doctor is a monkey.'
And monkeys can\xc2\x92t write out prescriptions.'
(stops laughing, to Ross) You are not allowed to laugh at my joke.'
Your joke? Well, I think \xc2\x91the Hef\xc2\x92 would disagree, which is why\nhe sent me a check for one hundred ah-dollars.'
So, you stole my joke, and you stole my money.'
Well, I was going to stick it in the ATM, but now I think I\xc2\x92ll show\nthe sexy teller that I am a published writer.'
Well, she is going to know that you stole the joke.'
Oh, what are you going to do, follow me down there?'
Yeah!'
Well, I\xc2\x92m not going to go now anyway (he goes to sit down).'
Okay (he goes to sit down).'
(handing Joey the bill) Here you go.'
Ah, Gunther, I can\xc2\x92t pay for this right now because I\xc2\x92m not\nworking, so I\xc2\x92ve had to cut down on some luxuries like uh, payin\xc2\x92 for stuff.'
Well, if you want, you can work here.'
Uh, I don\xc2\x92t know. Ya see, it\xc2\x92s just, see I was a regular on a\nsoap opera y\xc2\x92know? And to go from that to this, I just\xc2\x85 Plus, I\xc2\x92d have to\nwait on all my friends.'
Okay, but the money\xc2\x92s good, plus you get to stare at Rachel as\nmuch as you want.'
What?!'
Flexible hours.'
Maybe I could be a waiter. Could I use the phone?'
(visibly upset) She picked Rachel. I mean, she tried to back out of it,\nbut it was obvious. She picked Rachel.'
(visibly upset) He took my joke, he took it. '
It\xc2\x92s wrong. You know what else is wrong? Phoebe picking Rachel.'

You know who else picked Rachel? Ross, and you know what else Ross\ndid? He stole my joke. You know what? I\xc2\x92m going to get a joke journal. Y\xc2\x92know?\nAnd document the date and time of every single one of my jokes.'
That\xc2\x92s a good idea. '
Yeah!'
Do you know what\xc2\x92s a bad idea?'
Picking Rachel.'
That\xc2\x92s right. (A noise comes from the living room.) Did you hear\nsomething?'
Maybe it\xc2\x92s the sound of Ross climbing into my brain and stealing\nmy thoughts.'
It\xc2\x92s coming from the living room.'
(sheepishly) I finished my book. (Chandler and Monica slowly retreat back\nto bed.)'
(entering) Hey, you guys.'
Hey.'
(laughing) Oh, don\xc2\x92t you guys look cute. You guys make\nsuch a cute couple.'
Monica, what are you doing?'
(laughing harder) Nothing, I\xc2\x92m just trying to recreate\nsome of the fun that we had at my place the other day. (To Phoebe) Remember, when you\npicked Rachel over me? That was funny.'
I guess it was kinda funny.'
(angrily) It wasn\xc2\x92t funny at all! Why would you do that?\nWhy didn\xc2\x92t you pick me?'
Fine. The reason that I was leaning a little bit more toward Rachel than\nyou is just that you\xc2\x92re \xc2\x85 just \xc2\x85 kinda high maintenance\xc2\x97Okay\nlet\xc2\x92s go to lunch!'
That is completely untrue. You think I\xc2\x92m high maintenance? Okay,\nprove it. I want you to make a list and we\xc2\x92re going to go through it point by point!'
No, okay, you\xc2\x92re right. You\xc2\x92re easy-going. You\xc2\x92re just\nnot as easy-going as Rachel. She\xc2\x92s just more flexible and-and mellow. That\xc2\x92s\nall.'
(To Monica) Well, people are different.'
Ya, you know, Rachel \xc2\x85 she\xc2\x92ll do whatever you want.\nY\xc2\x92know, you can just walk all over her.'
What? Wait a minute. What are you saying, that I\xc2\x92m a pushover?\nI\xc2\x92m not a pushover.'
Oh, okay, (laughing) you\xc2\x92re not a pushover.'

Oh my \xc2\x85 you think I\xc2\x92m a pushover. Well wait, watch this, you
know what? You\xc2\x92re not invited to lunch. What do you think of that? I think
that\xc2\x92s pretty strong, that\xc2\x92s what I think. Come on, Monica, let\xc2\x92s go to
lunch. (She leaves)'
(to Phoebe) You start working on that list. (She grabs her\ncoat and leaves, too.)'
I cannot believe her.'
I know. Where do you wanna go eat?'
Oh, oh, I love that Japanese place.'
I\xc2\x92m sick of Japanese. We\xc2\x92re not going there.'
All right, wherever you wanna go is cool.'
All right.'
(showing the Playboy magazine to Gunther) Oh, hey, Gunther, check this\nout.'
Yeah, that-that Chandler cracks me up. '
Hey Ross, listen, you want anything to drink, \xc2\x91cause I\xc2\x92m heading\nup there.'
Uh, yeah, I\xc2\x92ll take a coffee. Thanks, man.'
Sure. (To Monica and Rachel) Coffee? \xc2\x91Cause I\xc2\x92m going up there. '
No.'
No, thank you.'
(to a table of strangers) You guys need anything, \xc2\x91cause I\xc2\x92m\nheading up there. '
I\xc2\x92d love an ice water.'
You got it.'
Joey, what are you doing?'
Just being friendly. (He gives Monica a \xc2\x91what\xc2\x92s wrong with\nyou?\xc2\x92 look and proceeds to walk behind the counter.)'
Joey, honey, I don\xc2\x92t think you\xc2\x92re supposed to go back there.'
Nah, it\xc2\x92s okay. Right, Gunther? (Winks at him as if they\xc2\x92re in\non a secret together.)'
Don\xc2\x92t wink at me. And put on your apron.'
Okay, but I don\xc2\x92t see you asking any other paying customers to put on\naprons. '
Joey, do you work here?'
No.'
Hey, waiter.'
Yeah?'
Joey, what\xc2\x92s going on. What didn\xc2\x92t you tell us you work here?'
It\xc2\x92s kind of embarrassing, y\xc2\x92know. I mean, I was an actor and\nnow I\xc2\x92m a waiter. It\xc2\x92s supposed to go in the other direction.'
So is your apron. You\xc2\x92re wearing it like a cape.'

I mean, the job\xc2\x92s easy and the money\xc2\x92s good, you know? I guess\nI\xc2\x92m going to be hanging out here anyway. I might as well get paid for it, right? I\njust feel kind of weird serving you guys.'
Come on, Joey, I did it and it was fine.'
Yeah, why would it be weird? Hey, Joey, can I get some coffee?'
Okay, I guess it doesn\xc2\x92t seem that weird.'
Seriously, I-I asked you before and you still haven\xc2\x92t gotten it.'
See, now it\xc2\x92s weird again.'
I think it\xc2\x92s great that you work here. You\xc2\x92re going to make\na lot of money, and here\xc2\x92s your first tip

Well, you know what? This is great. Finally, I have someone I can pass
on my wisdom too. Let me tell you about a couple of things I learned while working at the
coffeehouse. First of all, the customer is always right. (Joey nods.) A smile goes a long
way. (Joey smiles) And if anyone is ever rude to you? Sneeze muffin.'
Thanks, Rach. Look, you guys are just terrific. Y\xc2\x92know? Now, how\nabout clearing out of here so I can get some new customers. It\xc2\x92s all about turnover.'
Joey, seriously, can I get my coffee?'
Oh, I\xc2\x92m sorry, Ross. I\xc2\x92ll get it for you right now. And since I\nmade you wait, I\xc2\x92ll toss in a free muffin.'
Phoebe. We would like to talk to you for a second.'
Okay.'
So, maybe I am a little high maintenance. And maybe Rachel is a little\nbit of a pushover. But you know what we decided you are?'
Yes, we are very sorry to tell you this, but you, Phoebe, are flaky.'
Hah!'
That true, I am flaky.'
So, what, you\xc2\x92re just, you\xc2\x92re just okay with being flaky?'
Yeah, totally.'
Well, then, I\xc2\x92m okay with being high maintenance.'
Yeah, and I am okay with being a pushover.'
That\xc2\x92s great. Good for you guys.'
I am not high maintenance!'
I am not a pushover!'
Who said you were?'
You did!'
Oh, I\xc2\x92m flaky. I\xc2\x92ll say anything.'
Hey, Gunther. Can you uh, can you cover for me? I just got an audition.'
No, I\xc2\x92m leaving to get my hair dyed.'

Really?! I like your natural color. Come on man, it\xc2\x92s a great part.\nLook, check it out. I\xc2\x92m the lead guy\xc2\x92s best friend and I wait for him in this\nbar and save his seat. Listen-listen. \xc2\x91I\xc2\x92m sorry, that seat\xc2\x92s saved.\xc2\x92'
That\xc2\x92s the whole part?'
Okay, I\xc2\x92ll see you in an hour.'
Oh, man, I could totally get that part. \xc2\x91I\xc2\x92m sorry, that seat is\ntaken.\xc2\x92'
Oh, excuse me.'
No, no, I didn\xc2\x92t mean you. But, you believed me, huh?'
I believed you were saving this seat for someone.'
So, you\xc2\x92d hire me, right?'
For what?'
Exactly! All right, everybody, listen up. The coffeehouse is going to be\nclosed for about an hour. '
Huh? What?'
Yeah, it\xc2\x92s for the kids. To keep the kids off drugs. It\xc2\x92s a very\nimportant issue in this month\xc2\x92s Playboy. I\xc2\x92m sure you all read about it.'
It\xc2\x92s my joke.'
It\xc2\x92s my joke.'
It\xc2\x92s my joke.'
Y\xc2\x92know, I don\xc2\x92t think we\xc2\x92re going to settle this.'
Let\xc2\x92s have Monica decide.'
Yeah!'
Yeah!'
Hey Mon.'
Mon, get out here!'
Monica! (She appears, not sure why she was summoned.)'
Okay, okay. You have to help us decide whose joke this is.'
Why do I have to decide?'
Because you\xc2\x92re the only one that can be fair.'
Yeah.'
I can\xc2\x92t be fair. You\xc2\x92re my boyfriend.'
Yeah, but I\xc2\x92m your brother. We\xc2\x92re family. That\xc2\x92s the most\nimportant thing in the world.'
(to Ross) Don\xc2\x92t try to sway her. (To Monica) (Softly) I\xc2\x92m\nyour only chance to have a baby. Okay, let\xc2\x92s go.'
We\xc2\x92ll each tell you how we came up with the joke and then you decide\nwhich one of us is telling the truth\xc2\x97me. '
Okay, Chandler, you go first.'
Okay, I thought of the joke two months ago at lunch with Steve.'
Oh, wait, is he the guy I met at Christmas?'
Can I finish my story?!'
Do you want me to pick you?!'
See, I would never snap at you like that.'
Continue.'

So Steve said he had to go to the doctor. And Steve\xc2\x92s
doctor\xc2\x92s name is Doctor Muppy. So I said, \xc2\x91Doctor Monkey?\xc2\x92 And that is how
the whole Doctor Monkey thing came up. (He slams his feet up on the table to emphasize his
point.)'
Are you kidding? Okay, look. I-I studied evolution. Remember, evolution?\nMonkey into man? Plus, I\xc2\x92m a doctor, and I had a monkey. I\xc2\x92m Doctor Monkey!'
I\xc2\x92m not arguing with that.'
All right, I\xc2\x92ve heard enough. I\xc2\x92ve made my decision.'

You are both idiots. The joke is not funny, and it\xc2\x92s offensive to
women, and doctors, and monkeys! You shouldn\xc2\x92t be arguing over who gets credit, you
should be arguing over who gets blamed for inflicting this horrible joke upon the world!
Now let it go! The joke sucks! '
It\xc2\x92s your joke.'
Is not.'
Hi, Chandler. There you are.'
Hi, oh hi.'
Hey, it\xc2\x92s Phoebe and Rachel. Um, why don\xc2\x92t you tell them what\nyou were telling me earlier about me not being high maintenance?'

(starts to recite a rehearsed speech) Monica is a self-sufficient,
together lady. (Pause.) Being with her has been like being on a vacation. And what may be
perceived as high maintenance is merely attention to detail and\xc2\x97(He falters and
Monica prompts him.)\xc2\x97generosity of spirit.'
Wow, you know what? That is the best fake speech I think I\xc2\x92ve ever\nheard.'
Really? I\xc2\x92ve heard better.'
Wait, wait, he came up with that himself. Tell them, Chandler.'
(To Chandler) I\xc2\x92m out of words. Should I just say the whole thing\nagain?'
Look, I am not high maintenance. I am not. Chandler!'
(pauses as he struggles with what he has to say) You\xc2\x92re a little\nhigh maintenance.'
Ahhh! You are on my list.'

I\xc2\x92m sorry. You\xc2\x92re not easy-going, but you\xc2\x92re
passionate, and that\xc2\x92s good. And when you get upset about the little things, I think
that I\xc2\x92m pretty good about making you feel better about that. And that\xc2\x92s good
too. So, they can say that you\xc2\x92re high maintenance, but it\xc2\x92s okay, because I
like \xc2\x85 maintaining you.'
(embarrassed) (To Phoebe and Rachel) I didn\xc2\x92t even tell him to say\nthat. (They hug). All right you\xc2\x92re off my list. '
(happily) I\xc2\x92m off the list. (Sits on the couch.) '
(sits next to him) Phoebe, it\xc2\x92s okay that you don\xc2\x92t want me to\nbe your girlfriend because I have the best boyfriend.'
(to Monica) Y\xc2\x92know, suddenly I find you very attractive.'
Hey, buddy boy, how\xc2\x92d the audition go?'
Not good, no. I didn\xc2\x92t get the part, and I lost my job here, so\n\xc2\x85'
Wow! That is a bad audition.'
How-how did you lose your job here?'
Well, I had the audition but Gunther said I had to stay here and be in\ncharge so he could go get his hair dyed. So, I went anyway, and then he fired me.'
He left work in the middle of the day to do a personal errand and left\nyou in charge when you\xc2\x92ve been working here two days? That\xc2\x92s not, that\xc2\x92s\nnot right.'
Yeah, what are ya gonna do?'

Joey, you can\xc2\x92t let him get away with that. Ya know what, I\xc2\x92m
not going to let him get away with that. I\xc2\x92m going to say something to him\xc2\x97No, I
really shouldn\xc2\x92t say anything\xc2\x97No, I should say something to him. (Goes to the
counter) Gunther, I want you to give Joey his job back. That is really not fair that you
have to fire him\xc2\x85'
Okay.'
What?'
He can have his job back.'
That\xc2\x92s right, he can have his job back. I\xc2\x92m glad we got that\nall straightened out. There you go, Joey, you got your job back.'
That\xc2\x92s great. Thanks Rach.'
Yeah, pretty nice, huh? Now who\xc2\x92s a pushover?'
(returning from the bathroom) Rach, you\xc2\x92re in my seat.'
Oh, I\xc2\x92m sorry. (Gets up and moves.)'
Hey, I never got to hear who you guys would pick to be your girlfriend.'
I pick you, Phoebe.'
Oh, yeah. Definitely you, Pheebs.'
Yeah, well, I kinda thought.'
Hey.'
Hey. Oh, I have a question. If-if-if one of you had to pick one of the\nother two guys to go out with, who would you pick?'
No way. '
I\xc2\x92m not answering that.'
Joey! (Pause as they all stare at him.) No way. I\xc2\x92m not answering\nthat. '
